articles.summary: Climate change and conflict are fuelling one another, leaving lasting environmental impact across war-struck regions of the world. CNA's Jack Board and Liling Tan discuss the latest research covering an overlooked factor in today's hot zones with Jack Board on CNA.

articles.title: UN warns world is barrelling past 1.5°C climate limit as planet heats up
articles.summary: There is a 70% chance that average warming from 2025 to 2029 will exceed the 1.5°C international benchmark. The 2015 Paris climate accords aimed to limit global warming to well below 2°C above pre-industrial levels and to 1. 5°C if possible. The targets are calculated relative to the 1850-1900 average.

articles.title: Record-high global temperatures likely to continue for next 5 years, scientists say

articles.summary: Temperatures for the globe are expected to remain at or near record levels during the next five years. Last year was Earth's warmest year on record. The report noted that the warming will bring wetter-than-average weather to Alaska, northern Europe, northern Siberia and South Asia.

articles.title: Scorching heat in Pakistan: A public health emergency
articles.author: Professor Khalid Mahmood Si
articles.summary: This summer, parts of Pakistan are reeling under an intense and prolonged heatwave. The heat is a growing public health emergency that threatens the lives and well-being of millions, especially the poor and vulnerable. People living in small homes with tin roofs, with limited or no access to electricity, clean drinking water, or cooling systems are at risk. Those who work outdoors, labourers, cart vendors, rickshaw drivers and farmers are at serious risk, as are children, elderly people and chronic illnesses.

articles.title: Idaho symposium links climate change to public health

articles.summary: Treasure Valley Climate and Health Symposium was held on May 16 in Boise, Idaho. It was organized by Dr. Wesley Pidcock, a pulmonologist at Saint Alphonsus, Dr. Kathryn Conlon, an assistant professor with University of California, Davis, and Dr. Ethan Sims, an emergency medical specialist with St. Luke's in Nampa, and a professor at Boise State University's Department of Geoscience and School of the Environment. articles.title: Antarctica's sea ice is changing, and so is a vital part of the marine food web that lives within it
articles.author: Jacqui Stuart
articles.summary: Antarctica's annual maximum sea ice extent in September 2023 was the lowest on record, with approximately 1.75 million square kilometres less than normal. For four of the last seven years, unseasonable winter southerly storms have been associated with significant delays in the timing of sea-ice formation within McMurdo Sound. When sea ice forms later, microalgal communities living within the ice are less diverse and dominated by fewer species.

There is an 80% chance that at least one year between 2025 and 2029 will set a new annual global temperature record. The planet is increasingly at risk of officially surpassing the 1.5 degree Celsius warming threshold established in the 2015 Paris Climate Agreement.

articles.title: Climate change linked to rising cancer rates among women in MENA: AUC study
articles.author: Mohammed El-Said
articles.summary: A new study by the American University in Cairo has found a significant association between rising temperatures and cancer incidence and mortality among women in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA). For every 1°C increase in average temperature, an additional 173 to 280 cancer cases and 171 to 332 cancer-related deaths occurred per 100,000 women in 17 MENA countries between 1998 and 2019. Qatar reported the sharpest increase in breast cancer incidence, followed by Bahrain with 330. The highest increase in mortality was linked to ovarian cancer, while cervical cancer showed the smallest change.

articles.summary: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) has issued its latest global climate update. It predicts that Earth's temperatures will remain at or near record highs through 2029. There is an 86% chance that one of these years will see temperatures more than 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels. The Paris Agreement aims to limit long-term global warming to well below 2°C.

The Arctic is forecast to warm more than 3.5 times the global average over the next five winters.

articles.title: New Analysis: IPCC's Emissions-Based Climate Model Errors So Massive They Eliminate Predictive Validity
articles.author: Kenneth Richard
articles.summary: The IPCC-favored climate model parameters used to support the narrative that climate change is primarily caused by humans burning fossil fuels are fraught with errors. The IPCC's Anthro models that hypothesize CO2 will foment dangerous global warming over the coming decades woefully overestimated the warming from 1970-2019 by anywhere from 1.8°C to 2.5°C. The authors conclude the models' unreliability 'would appear to void policy relevance'

articles.summary: Record temperatures and wildfires threaten Greece's most-visited site. The Athens Acropolis faces closures during peak heat. Climate change is affecting tourism and cultural tourism in Greece, especially in terms of climate change tourism.   Â   in the Acropolis.

articles.title: Peruvian farmer's decade-long climate battle against RWE ends in German court
articles.author: system
articles.summary: A German court has ruled against a Peruvian farmer in a landmark climate lawsuit. Activists say the decision opens the door for major greenhouse gas emitters to be held financially liable in such a case.       in the future, they say.

articles.title: What Trump's climate science crackdown means for global forecasts
articles.author: Swissinfo
articles.summary: US President Donald Trump has launched an unprecedented assault on environmental and climate initiatives. This includes cuts to US scientific agencies. If enacted, these cuts would hurt other nations' abilities to accurately forecast the weather, warn scientists and the World Meteorological Organization (WMO).

articles.title: UN says strong chance average warming will top 1.5 degrees Celsius in next 4 years
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: The planet is expected to remain at historic levels of warming after the two hottest years ever recorded in 2023 and 2024, according to an annual UN report. There is a 70 per cent chance that average warming from 2025 to 2029 would exceed the 1.5 degrees celsius international benchmark.
